fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Category of elements of a regular hyperdoctrine

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If T is a regular hyperdoctrine, then the category of elements \mathsf {Elts}( T ) is a regular category.

A regular hyperdoctrine T \colon \mathcal { C } ^ \mathrm {op} \to \mathsf { CAT } is said to have comprehension schema if the naming functor { \mathopen {}[ \mathord { \hspace {1pt} \text {--} \hspace {1pt}} ] \mathclose {}} _{X} admits a right adjoint { \mathopen {} \{ X \colon \mathord { \hspace {1pt} \text {--} \hspace {1pt}} \} \mathclose {}} for all object X \in \mathcal { C }.

Let \mathcal { C } be a category with finite limits. A regular hyperdoctrine T \colon \mathcal { C } ^ \mathrm {op} \to \mathsf { CAT } (or elementary existential doctrine) is a doctrine satisfying the following conditions:

fr:ul.fr:li: For each object X \in \mathcal { C }, the fiber T(X) has finite limits.
For each morphism f \colon X \to Y in \mathcal { C }, f ^{*} admits a left adjoint \Sigma _{f}.
Each left adjoint \Sigma _{f} satisfies the Beck-Chevalley condition.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subobject doctrine of a regular category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal { C } be a regular category, then the subobject doctrine \mathsf { Sub } \colon \mathcal { C } ^ \mathrm {op} \to \mathsf { CAT } is a regular hyperdoctrine with comprehension schema.

First, each fiber \mathsf { Sub } (A) has finite limits inherited from \mathcal { C }. By , each f ^{*} has the required left adjoint \exists _{f}. They satisfy the Beck-Chevalley condition because images commute with pullbacks in a regular category. Then the naming functor { \mathopen {}[ \mathord { \hspace {1pt} \text {--} \hspace {1pt}} ] \mathclose {}} _{X} \colon { \mathcal { C } _{/{ X }}} \to \mathsf { Sub } (X) is precisely the image \mathsf { Img }, which admits the inclusion functor as a right adjoint.

A category \mathcal { C } is said to be regular if it is cartesian, has images, and covers are stable under pullback. A functor F \colon \mathcal { C } \to \mathcal { D } between regular categories is said to be regular if it is cartesian and preserves covers. Note that since cartesian functors preserve monomorphisms, every regular functor automatically preserves images.

Let F \colon \mathcal { C } \to \mathcal { D } be a regular functor and f \colon A \to B be a morphism in \mathcal { C }. By , f admits a cover-mono factorization f = \mathsf { Img } (f) \vartheta _{f}. Then since F preserves monomorphisms and covers, F( \mathsf { Img } (f))F( \vartheta _{f}) forms a cover-mono factorization of F(f). Then by uniqueness, \mathsf { Img } (Ff) \cong F( \mathsf { Img } (f)).
